metadata.title: Experimental investigation of switchable behavior of CuO- MWCNT (85%–15%)/10W-40 hybrid nano-lubricants for applications in internal combustion engines

sections.text:
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
In this study, we examined the rheological behavior of hybrid nano-lubricant CuOMWCNT (85% -15%) / 10W-40 at the temperature range of 5 to 55°C and the solid volume fraction of 0.05 to 1% to use in internal combustion engines. According to experimental data, by increasing the solid volume fraction, the amount of nanolubricant viscosity increases compared with pure lubricant, so that the maximum amount of dynamic viscosity enhancement in solid volume fraction of 1% is about 43.52 %. Nano-lubricant behavior is diagnosed by using the Herschel-Bulkley (type Bingham) model, so that in temperatures less than 45°C, nano-lubricant shows nonNewtonian behavior of Bingham pseudoplastic, and it shows Bingham plastic nonNewtonian behavior at temperatures above 45°C. Finally, to predict the dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant, a mathematical correlation with second order precision of 0.9846 was presented, which it had acceptable match with experimental data.
Keywords: Hybrid nano-lubricants, CuO-MWCNT, Bingham behavior, non-
Newtonian, new correlation, DVE.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
1-Introdution
Lubricants play undeniable and crucial role in mechanical systems so that several studies have been conducted by scientists to improve thermo-physical properties, especially dynamic viscosity[1]. One of the most widely used types of liquid oils is combustion engine oils. In order to increase the quality of engine oil to increase efficiency and life of internal combustion engines, researchers tested a new strategy by adding nanoparticle to base oil[2]–[9]. Nanofluid was tested in 1995 by Choi[10] by adding metal nanoparticle to water in order to examine the rate of increasing in its thermal conductivity. In general, suspensions containing the mixture of metal, oxide, or carbon particles with size of 1 to 100 nm with a base fluid, such as water[11], [12], ethylene glycol[13], [14], and engine oil[15] are called nanofluid. According to most of the studies, nanofluids have superior thermal and thermo-physical properties compared to common fluids (water, ethylene glycol, oil, etc.)[16]–[20]. This important property in nanofluids leads to its widely use in industries such as heat exchangers[21], heating and cooling systems[22], solar collectors[23], [24], and medical nuclear systems[25], internal combustion engines[26], and military industries[27]. Additionally, nanofluids shrink engineering systems and save energy consumption and consequently reduce the costs[28], [29]. Due to superior thermophysical properties of nano-lubricants compared with pure engine oils, researchers try to use nano-lubricants in internal combustion engines, because nano-lubricants due to having thermal conductivity and high dynamic viscosity have greater ability to tolerate shear force and better transfer of heat[30]. As a result, these two parameters increase the efficiency and life of combustion engine parts, especially cylinder and piston[31]. In this respect, Hemmat Esfe et al.[2] In an experimental study examined the dynamic viscosity of hybrid nano-lubricant MWCNT / ZnO-SAE40 at 25 to 60°C and solid volume fractions of 0.05 to 1%. According to recorded reports, the considered nano-lubricant viscosity reduces by increasing solid volume fraction of nanoparticles and by increasing temperature. The maximum increase of viscosity compared to pure engine oil in the solid volume fraction of 1% and a temperature of 40°C has been reported about 33.3 percent. More recently, in another study conducted by Hemmat Esfe et al.[32], the effect of temperature and carbon nanotubes on rheological behavior of nano-lubricant 10W-40 in solid the volume fractions of 0.025 to 0.75 percent and the shear rate of 666 to 13333 per second was studied. With regard to the viscosities measured in different shear rates, nanofluid behavior in all samples has been reported non-Newtonian and nano-lubricant in viscosity solid volume fraction in its maximum amount is about 2.5 times of pure lubricant. In an experimental study, Kole and T.K. Dey[33] investigated the dynamic viscosity and thermal conductivity of nanofluid Cu/gear oil. In accordance with the results obtained, by adding 2% volume of nanoparticle, dynamic viscosity and thermal conductivity increased approximately 71 and 24 percent, respectively. This amount of increasing in viscosity leads to better maintaining of oil film on gears. Toghraei et al.[34] Also examined the viscosity of water-based nanofluid containing magnetic nanoparticles (Fe3O4) to use in heating and cooling systems. According to the results, by adding 3% volume of nanoparticles to considered base fluid, the viscosity of nanofluid will increase about 129.7 percent which is significant amount. In this study, an equation was presented to predict the viscosity of magnetic nanofluid (Fe3O4/Water), which it
had acceptable match with measured experimental data. Table 1 shows an example of theoretical and experimental correlations provided by researchers in papers to predict the viscosity of nanofluids.

Whither nano-lubricant is Newtonian or non-Newtonian plays determining role in thermo-physical properties, and finally combustion engine function. In an experimental investigation, Aberoumand et al.[5] studies the rheological behavior of nanofluids Silver- Heat Transfer Oil at 25 to 60 ° C, and they found that with increasing of solid volume fraction of nanoparticles at temperatures lower than 35°C, nanofluid will show Newtonian behavior, and in temperatures higher than 35°C, it will show non-Newtonian behavior. Recently, Baojie Wei et al.[6], in an experimental study, examined thermal conductivity and dynamic viscosity of base nanofluid of diathermic oil. They observed that in the used temperatures, the amount of shear viscosity remains constant with increasing of shear rate that reflects the Newtonian behavior of fluid. Table 2 shows the rheological behavior of a number of nanofluids studied by researchers.

Carbon nanotubes compared to metal and non-metal nanoparticles cause a significant increasing in thermal properties of nanofluids due to having very high thermal conductivity. However, due to the high cost of the nanotubes, the researchers plan to use a mixture of nanotubes and oxide nanoparticles known as hybrid nanoparticles. This also results in a significant reduction in cost of nanofluids production and a significant increase in thermal conductivity and viscosity of them[53], [54]. According to the author investigation, few accurate and systematic studies have been conducted on rheological behavior of hybrid nanofluids, especially nano-lubricants. In this experimental study, we studied for the first time the rheological behavior of hybrid nano-lubricants containing multi-walled carbon nanotubes and copper oxide nanoparticles for the proper functioning in internal combustion engines. Additionally, for the first time, the effect of solid volume fraction, temperature, and shear rate on dynamic viscosity of hybrid nano-lubricants was tested. Then, in order to accurately prediction of the dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant, a mathematical correlation was presented to model it.

2-Experiments
Analyzed hybrid nano-lubricant was prepared from combination of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) and copper oxide nanoparticles (CuO) in the engine oil 10w-40. Nanoparticles have been distributed with ratio of 15 to 85% in the base fluid. Table 3 shows the thermo-physical properties of engine oil 10w-40[55]. Using Equation 1, the required mass of nanoparticles in different solid volume fractions was calculated.

Also, the photograph of nano-lubricant is presented in Fig. 1(b).Nanoparticles were prepared from famous company of US NANO. According to Figure 1, the mean diameter of the copper oxide nanoparticles is about 40 nm and the internal and external diameter of carbon nanotubes was calculated 3-5 and 5-15 nm, respectively, which the used nanoparticles have desired quality.

The common two-step method was used for the preparation of nanofluid. First, carbon nanotubes and copper oxide nanoparticles were weighted using a digital scale with accuracy of 0.0015. Then, nanoparticles were mixed with 10W-40 oil. The resulting solution was stirred by a stirrer for one hour. Ultrasonic homogenizer (manufactured by Kimia Nano-Knowledge Company, Iran) was used for 4 hours with the power of 1200 watts and a frequency of 20.8 kHz to eliminate possible agglomerates of nanoparticles.
The Viscosity of pure lubricant and hybrid nano-lubricant in solid volume fraction of 0.05%, 0.1%, 0.25%, 0.75%, and 1% was measured. Experiments were performed at the shear rates of 2666.6 to 11999.(1/s) and temperature of 5, 15, 25, 35, 45 and 55°C.

sections.heading: 2.1. The accuracy of measurements
sections.text:
For calibration of device, dynamic viscosity of pure ethylene glycol mixture with water at a ratio of 50% to 50% was measured in terms of temperature increasing. Then, experimental data obtained by the study Chiam et al.[45] were compared according to Figure 2.
Fig. 2. Comparing the data of EG/Water (50%-50%) viscosity in Chiam et al study and those in the present study.
According to Figure 2, the data measured in this study at shear rate of 6666.9 S -1 have acceptable match with the data of Chiam et al.[45]. As a result, calibration of the used viscometer is acceptable.
To minimize the effects of repeatability, experiments were performed in all shear rates, the solid volume fraction, and different temperatures and mean data obtained by the dynamic viscosity have been listed in Table 4.

sections.heading: 3.1. Investigating the rheological behavior of nanofluids
sections.text:
To study the rheological behavior of nanofluids, according to Figure 3, shear stress and apparent viscosity of hybrid nano-lubricants and pure lubricant 10W-40 were plotted in terms of shear rate at different temperature and solid volume fractions. According to this Figure, the behavior of MWCNT-CuO (15%-85%)/10W40 nanolubricant is non-Newtonian in all temperatures ranges and the solid volume fractions for two reasons. The first reason is reduction in apparent viscosity with increasing of shear rate at all temperatures ranges and solid volume fractions which is plotted in figure 3. Which in Newtonian fluids, apparent viscosity does not change with increasing shear rate. The second reason is non-linear changes of shear stress with shear rate, since the diagram of shear stress versus shear rate does not pass origin of coordinates for all temperatures ranges and solid volume fractions. Rheological behavior of fluids can be classified as shown in Figure 4.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U

IP T
Fig. 3. apparent viscosity and shear stress in terms of shear rate in different solid volume faction and temperatures.
Fig. 4. Different types of fluid rheology behaviors.

respect to shear rate begins from the yeild stress point. This equation is expressed as follows:
(2)
In this equation, t and K are structure-dependent parameters, indicates shear rate and τy indicates yield-stress parameter. The behavior of fluids according to this model is Bingham. According to Figure 4, t value (less than 1, equal to 1, or greater than 1) determines the pseudoplastic and dilatant behavior or linear change with an initial yield stress. Ostwald de Waele equation model is expressed as follows:
(3)
In this equation, reflects the shear rate, n is power-law index, and m indicates consistency-index. This equation is used for non-Newtonian fluids that the diagram of the shear stress changing in terms of their shear rate passes origin of coordinates. In this equation, n greater than 1 indicates the pseudoplastic fluid behavior (shear thinning) and n less than 1 indicates the dilatant fluid behavior (shear thickening) (see Figure 5).
According to shear stress-shear rate diagram, the relevant values with curve fitting were inserted in two considered models and consequently, R-squared related to two models in each temperature and solid volume fraction is obtained According to the obtained R-square by the two mentioned models, the Herschel-Bulkley model fit on the experimental data of the studied Nano-lubricant is more accurate. Therefore, the studied hybrid nano-lubricant acts according to Bingham non-Newtonian behavior and the changes of shear stress begin with initial yield stress. Tables 5 to 7 show the coefficients values related to this model.

Figure 5 shows the yield stress changes for hybrid nano-lubricant in solid volume fractions and different temperature ranges. According to the Figure and Table 5, it can be found that changes of the yield stress for each temperature and solid volume fraction are not zero, which this subject proves Bingham behavior of nanofluids. In fact, shear rate caused that the shear stress with initial propulsion that is the yield stress begins to change. For more explanation, Bingham behavior can be expressed so that by adding nanoparticles to the pure lubricant (Due to the high level of their energy), nanoparticles have a type of collision, which caused a poor structure is formed, as previously known as a false body. To break the false body, an initial stress that is yield stress is required so that the nano-lubricant to move. By breaking false body, nanoparticles move with oil flow. However, by reducing yield stress, nanolubricant stops and the mentioned structure is reformed. In this Figure, the effect of temperature on yield stress can be seen. According to this Figure, at low temperatures, the changes in yield stress in various solid volume fractions are small, stable, and less than zero, but by increasing the temperature, stability of yield stress reduced significantly, so that the rate of the yield stress changes in various solid volume fractions is from -213.2 to 112.8 mpa.s. The reason is justified by the fact that by increasing temperature, the energy level of nanoparticles increased and finally it caused severe changes in the yield stress of nano-lubricants.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Fig. 5. changes of yield stress index in terms of solid volume fraction and temperature. Figure 6 shows the K index changing versus temperature. According to this Figure, at the low temperatures (5°C to 35°C), the rate of changes in the K index for different solid volume fractions is very low and negligible. However, at high temperatures (45°C to 55°C), K index changes is increasing. At temperature of 55°C, solid volume fractions of 0.25 and 0.5% with pure lubricant 10W-40, K index is close to zero. In these examples, the impact of Kγ̇t in Equation 2 is negligible, and it can be said that the yield stress is almost equal with shear stress ( HB y  ) and it will play a significant role in rheological behavior of studied hybrid nano-lubricant.
Fig. 6. K index changes in terms of temperature. In Figure 7, structural changes process of parameter t in terms of temperature is shown on different solid volume fractions. According to the Figure, at temperatures lower than 45°C, the parameter t in all solid volume fractions is less than one, so hybrid nano-lubricant shows non-Newtonian behavior of Bingham pseudoplastic. At a temperature of 55°C and solid volume fractions of less than 0.5%, fluid behavior has changed to Bingham plastic. In the above figure, Sensible impact of temperature on the rheological behavior of hybrid nano-lubricant is visible.

sections.heading: 3.2. The effects of concentration and temperature on dynamic viscosity
sections.text:
In Figure 8, the amount of dynamic viscosity enhancement (DVE) of hybrid nano in terms of temperature and solid volume fraction is shown. As shown, by increasing the solid volume fraction, DVE also increased, due to Van der Waals force among nanomolecules causing that they stick together resulting in cluster effect formation in nono-lubricants. Finally, by forming the cluster effect, friction between layers of oils, led and increase in its dynamic viscosity compared to pure lubricant. By increasing the dynamic viscosity, Consequently, DVE also increased. According to the table, DVE of nano-lubricant compared to pure lubricant was obtained 43.52% at a temperature of 55°C and solid volume fraction of 1%. The rate of this increment is used in industries that require high dynamic viscosity, such as internal combustion engines[26].
Due to the operating temperature increasing in the summer, the viscosity is further reduced compared to the winter. This would be problematic in the absence of compensation for viscosity reduction for parts of combustion engines. For that purpose, the viscosity should be

increased to maintain the oil film on the pieces. The most modern and most intelligent way to raise the viscosity can be adding nanoparticles to be pure oil [57] because the addition of nanoparticles increases the thermal conductivity as well as the viscosity. This prevents the sharp rise in oil temperature and therefore a sharp decrease in its viscosity in critical conditions. Ultimately, improving the quality of conventional oils causes advantages that
include [58]:
 Easier starting the engine followed by reducing engine wear, increasing the start and
battery life.
 Lower fuel consumption (in some cases may affect up to 3% on fuel consumption).
 The use of an oil throughout the year and higher efficiency at high temperatures.
 Reducing the amount of oil burning.

sections.heading: 3.3. Proposed correlation
sections.text:
In order to provide new correlation to predict the dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricants, curve fitting was carried out on the experimental data. This correlation was obtained as follows:
(4)
In this correlation, bf and nf are abbreviation for the base fluid and nanofluid and φ indicates the solid volume fraction of nano-lubricant. This correlation was derived by Design Expert software. According to Table 8, the second-order precision(R-square) of equation was obtained 0.9842. The presented correlation has been validated in the solid volume fraction of 0.05 to 1% and temperatures of 5 to 55 °C to predict the dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant MWCNT-CuO (15% -85%) / 10W40.
Table 8. The second order precision of presented equation.
Std. Dev. 7.485E-003 R-Squared 0.9846 Mean 1.08 Adj R-Squared 0.9801 C.V. % 0.69 Pred R-Squared 0.9706 PRESS 2.891E-003 Adeq Precision 50.515 According to Figure 9, theoretical models of Einstein[35], Brinkman[38], Simha et al. [59], Chen et al.[60] and Wang et al.[10] were used to predict dynamic viscosity on hybrid nano-lubricant and comparison of the results of theoretical models, presented correlation, and experimental data are seen. As shown in Figure, theoretical models unlike the presented correlation have high errors in predicting dynamic viscosity and the lowest error related to the Chen et al model.

Fig. 9. A comparison between theoretical models, suggested correlation, and experimental data of relative viscosity.
In Figure 10, the diagram of margin of deviation (MOD) amount in terms of solid volume fraction of nanoparticles at different temperatures and a comparative diagram between experimental data and presented correlation have been shown. MOD is defined according to equation 5.

According to the figure, maximum amount of MOD is at a temperature of 5°C and solid volume fraction of 0.25% that it is around -3.8 percent. In general, accuracy of the provided correlation is acceptable due to low level of error.
Fig. 10. Margin of deviation (MOD) of new correlation at various temperatures and solid volume fractions.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this experimental study, we examined the rheological behavior of hybrid nanolubricant with base oil 10W-40 containing 15% of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) (internal diameter of 3-5 nm and external diameter of 5-15 nm) and 85%

copper oxide nanoparticles (mean diameter of 40 nm) at temperature 5-55 C °, the solid volume fractions of 0.05 to 1% and shear rates of 2666.6 to 11999.7(1/s). The results of this study are:
 rheological behavior of studied nano-lubricant is according to HerschelBulkley model and Bingham non-Newtonian behavior so that in all solid
volume fractions with a temperature less than 45°C, nanofluid is in accordance with Bingham and pseudoplastic non-Newtonian behavior, and at temperatures above 45°C and the solid volume fractions less than 0.5%, the behavior of nanofluids is Bingham plastic.
 The maximum dynamic viscosity enhancement (DVE) of nano-lubricant compared to the pure lubricant is about 43.52% at a temperature of 55°C and a
solid volume fraction of 1%, and it increases by increasing the solid volume fraction of DVE.
 To predict the dynamic viscosity of hybrid nano-lubricant, a new correlation with R-squared of 0.9846 was proposed that it had good match with
experimental data, so that the maximum amount of MOD is about -3.8%.

As a result, these two parameters increase the efficiency and life of combustion engine parts, especially cylinder and piston[31].

metadata.abstractText: In this study, we examined the rheological behavior of hybrid nano-lubricant CuOMWCNT (85% -15%) / 10W-40 at the temperature range of 5 to 55°C and the solid volume fraction of 0.05 to 1% to use in internal combustion engines. According to experimental data, by increasing the solid volume fraction, the amount of nanolubricant viscosity increases compared with pure lubricant, so that the maximum amount of dynamic viscosity enhancement in solid volume fraction of 1% is about 43.52 %. Nano-lubricant behavior is diagnosed by using the Herschel-Bulkley (type Bingham) model, so that in temperatures less than 45°C, nano-lubricant shows nonNewtonian behavior of Bingham pseudoplastic, and it shows Bingham plastic nonNewtonian behavior at temperatures above 45°C. Finally, to predict the dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant, a mathematical correlation with second order precision of 0.9846 was presented, which it had acceptable match with experimental data.
